title: 108_s759
content: The Act is titled the "Residential, Farm, Ranch, and Small Business Wind Energy Systems Act of 2003" or the "Small Wind Energy Systems Act of 2003." It introduces a credit for residential small wind energy systems under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act allows a 30% tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures made by individuals. The credit is limited to $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity and requires property to meet safety certifications. Unused credits can be carried forward to the next taxable year. Qualified wind energy property expenditure is defined as an expenditure for wind energy property installed on a dwelling unit in the US used as a residence by the taxpayer, including installation fees. The property must be a qualifying wind turbine with a 5-year limited warranty. Expenditures for labor costs related to the onsite preparation, assembly, or original installation of qualified wind energy property, including piping or wiring for connection to the dwelling unit or energy grid, are eligible under this section. A qualifying wind turbine is defined as a turbine with a rated capacity of 75 kilowatts or less, meeting performance standards at the time of manufacture, and used for electricity generation. Labor costs for installation are included in the qualified wind energy property expenditure. Expenditures related to energy storage mediums like swimming pools are not considered for this section. Special rules apply for joint occupancy dwelling units, treating all occupants as one taxpayer for the purpose of determining the allowable credit. Taxpayers can claim a credit for energy-related expenditures in the taxable year. Tenant-stockholders in cooperative housing corporations are considered to have made a share of the corporation's expenditures. Individuals in condominiums are also eligible for the credit. Individuals who are members of a condominium management association owning a condominium are treated as having made their share of the association's expenditures. The term 'condominium management association' refers to an organization meeting specific requirements with units used as residences. If less than 80 percent of a qualified wind energy property is used for nonbusiness purposes, only that portion of expenditures for the property is eligible for credit. For qualified wind energy property, expenditures are allocated for nonbusiness purposes and energy generation for sale. Expenditures are considered made when the property is installed and begins generating energy. The cost of the expenditure is the amount taken into account. The taxpayer's expenditures for qualified wind energy property are subject to basis adjustments and a credit reduction. The section does not apply to property installed after December 31, 2008. The credit can be used against regular tax and alternative minimum tax. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property is subject to limitations based on the amount of tax. The credit cannot exceed the sum of the regular tax liability and the tax imposed by section 55, minus the credits allowable under this subpart and section 27 for the taxable year. Conforming amendments are made to related sections of the Internal Revenue Code. Conforming amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code, including inserting section 25C in multiple sections and amending references to sections 23, 25B, and 25C. Conforming amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code, including inserting section 25C in multiple sections and amending references to sections 23, 25B, and 1400C. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include section 25C after section 25B in subpart A of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The amendments made by section 25C on residential wind energy property apply to expenditures after December 31, 2002, in taxable years ending after that date. The amendments made by subsection (b) apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2003. Additionally, a credit for business installation of small wind energy property is provided in section 3. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include qualified wind energy property installed before January 1, 2009. The term 'qualified wind energy property' refers to a qualifying wind turbine installed on a farm, ranch, or eligible small business in the United States. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property in the United States is limited to 30% of the property's basis, including installation fees, with a minimum 5-year warranty required. The tax credit for qualifying wind energy property in the US is limited to 30% of the property's basis or $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity. A qualifying wind turbine is defined as one with a rated capacity of 75 kilowatts or less meeting performance standards. Safety certifications are required for the credit to be allowed. The tax credit for qualifying wind energy property in the US is limited to 30% of the property's basis or $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity. Other energy properties receive a 10% credit. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code specify these percentages and apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2003.
